title: Letter: It's time 007 let out the seams and looked the part
text:
Robert Armstrong's article “Bond's suits: the Spectre of tight tailoring” (Life & Arts, FT Weekend, October 23) was reassuring. I have always taken pride in my appearance, even winning “best dressed in high school” — admittedly a dubious achievement.

I believe it was my traditional tailoring that helped me gain admission to Cornell University and the various law firms I worked for during law school. By the time I started my Wall Street career at Salomon Brothers when it was still a partnership, I had learned the value of appearances in the professional world.

So to me, the way Daniel Craig as James Bond wore his suit, looking as if he had outgrown it 10 years ago, was foolish. Fortunately fashion changes and I hope this constricting style is soon history.

For I think the only people who benefit from such ill-fitting attire are the manufacturers that save on the cost of the cloth to produce such garments. Time to let out the seams and look the part 007!

Steven A Ludsin
East Hampton, NY, US
